text: Origins in Tigris Valley. Pickling began around 2030 BC in the Tigris Valley. Native cucumbers were pickled to preserve them for out-of-season consumption.
Cleopatra's Beauty Secret. Cleopatra attributed her beauty and health to a diet of pickles.
Roman Soldier Fuel. Julius Caesar fed pickles to his troops, believing they gave them physical and spiritual strength.
Columbus and Vitamin C. Amerigo Vespucci and Christopher Columbus stored pickles on their ships to prevent scurvy among the crew.
Shakespearean Metaphor. Shakespeare was one of the first to use 'in a pickle' in The Tempest, though he meant being drunk, not just in trouble.
Thomas Jefferson's Quote. "On a hot day in Virginia, I know nothing more comforting than a fine spiced pickle, brought up trout-like from the sparkling depths of the aromatic jar."
Napoleon's Prize. Napoleon offered a prize of 12,000 francs to anyone who could preserve food for his army. This led to the boiling process used in pickling.
The 57 Varieties. H.J. Heinz introduced the 'pickle pin' at the 1893 Chicago World's Fair to attract customers to his booth.
Kosher Pickles in NYC. Jewish immigrants arriving in New York during the late 19th century introduced Kosher dill pickles to America.
Fermentation Science. Lactobacillus bacteria digest sugars in the cucumber, producing lactic acid which preserves the vegetable and gives the sour taste.
Kool-Aid Pickles. In the Mississippi Delta, pickles marinated in Kool-Aid (fruit punch or cherry) are a popular sweet-and-sour snack.
Pickle Juice for Athletes. Some athletes drink pickle juice to treat muscle cramps. The vinegar is thought to trigger a reflex that stops the cramping.
The Christmas Pickle. A German-American tradition involves hiding a pickle ornament on the Christmas tree. The first child to find it gets an extra present.
Cornichons. Tiny French pickles made from gherkins, typically served with pâté and raclette.
Kimchi. Korea's national dish, kimchi, is a variety of salted and fermented vegetables, usually napa cabbage and Korean radishes.
Branston Pickle. A British jarred pickled chutney made from swede, carrots, onions, and cauliflower in a thick sweet brown sauce.
Mango Pickle (Achar). A staple in South Asian cuisine, made from raw mangoes, oil, and a mix of spices like mustard seeds and fenugreek.
Pickled Eggs. Hard-boiled eggs cured in vinegar or brine. A common snack in British pubs and American bars.
Sauerkraut. Finely cut raw cabbage that has been fermented by various lactic acid bacteria.
Giardiniera. An Italian relish of pickled vegetables in vinegar or oil, often used on beef sandwiches in Chicago.
Tsukemono. Japanese preserved vegetables served with rice as an okazu (side dish) or with drinks as an otsumami (snack).
Picklebacks. A shot of whiskey followed immediately by a shot of pickle brine.
Nutritional Value. Pickles are high in Vitamin K but can be very high in sodium due to the brine.
The pH Level. For safe pickling, the acidity needs to be high enough (pH below 4.6) to kill botulism bacteria.
Bread and Butter Pickles. A sweet and tangy profile, traditionally made with cucumber, onion, and bell peppers.
Gherkin vs Cucumber. A gherkin is a variety of cucumber, usually harvested when small specifically for pickling.
Half-Sours. Pickles that haven't fully fermented. They are still crisp and bright green, popular in New York delis.
Deep Fried Pickles. A Southern US delicacy where pickle slices or spears are battered and fried.
Pickle Relish. Cooked and pickled chopped vegetables, a standard topping for hot dogs in North America.
Umeboshi. Japanese pickled plums (ume), known for being extremely sour and salty.
Preserved Lemon. Lemons pickled in salt and their own juices, essential in Moroccan tagines.
Pickled Herring. A traditional dish in Scandinavia and the Netherlands, herring cured in vinegar.
Pickled Watermelon Rind. A Southern US classic making use of the leftover rind, sweet and spiced with cloves.
Pickled Walnuts. A traditional English pickle made from green walnuts before the shells have formed.
Pickle Worms. The pickleworm is a moth larva that is a major pest to cucumber and squash plants.
Department of Agriculture. The USDA has specific grades for pickles based on size, flavor, and texture.
National Pickle Day. Celebrated on November 14th in the United States.
Perfect Burger Topping. The acidity of pickles cuts through the fat of the meat and cheese in a burger.
Refrigerated vs Shelf. Shelf-stable pickles are pasteurized (cooked), while refrigerated ones are often fermented live (raw).
Pickle Lingo: Polliwog. Industry slang for a cucumber that is completely misshapen.
Pickle Lingo: Nubbin. A crooked or short cucumber.
Mass Production. Americans consume over 2.5 billion pounds of pickles each year.
Electrolytes. Pickle brine is rich in electrolytes, which is why it's gaining popularity as a sports recovery drink.
DIY Pickling. Quick pickling involves simply pouring hot vinegar brine over veggies and refrigerating; no canning required.
Pickled Garlic. Often turns blue or green due to a reaction between enzymes and sulfur, but is safe to eat.
Pickle Festivals. Pittsburgh, PA and Winchester, NH host large annual pickle festivals.
Famous Brands. Vlasic, Claussen, and Mt. Olive are among the largest mass-market producers.
Artisanal Boom. Small-batch pickling has seen a resurgence with craft flavors like spicy maple or whiskey dill.
Sound Crunch. A 'good' pickle should be audible from 10 paces when bitten into, according to old marketing lore.
Space Pickles. Pickles have not yet been grown in space, but preserved foods are a staple of astronaut diets.
Solar Mass Dominance. The Sun accounts for 99.86% of the mass in our entire solar system.
Neutron Star Density. A teaspoon of neutron star material would weigh about 6 billion tons.
Silent Space. Space is completely silent because there is no atmosphere to carry sound waves.
Venus Day vs Year. A day on Venus is longer than a year on Venus due to its slow rotation.
Footprints on the Moon. The footprints on the Moon will be there for 100 million years because there is no wind to erode them.
Blue Sunset on Mars. Sunsets on Mars appear blue to human observers due to the fine dust in the atmosphere.
Largest Volcano. Olympus Mons on Mars is the largest volcano in the solar system, three times the height of Everest.
Diamond Rain. It rains diamonds on Saturn and Jupiter due to the intense pressure turning carbon into crystal.
Galactic Center Smell. The center of the Milky Way smells like raspberries and tastes like rum due to ethyl formate.
Expanding Universe. The universe is expanding faster than the speed of light.
Voyager 1 Distance. Voyager 1 is the most distant human-made object, currently in interstellar space.
Light Year. A light-year is the distance light travels in one year, about 5.88 trillion miles.
Number of Stars. There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the beaches on Earth.
Cold Welding. If two pieces of the same type of metal touch in space, they will bond and be permanently stuck together.
Dark Matter. Dark matter makes up about 27% of the universe, but we cannot see or detect it directly.
Great Red Spot. Jupiter's Great Red Spot is a storm that has been raging for at least 400 years.
Exoplanets. We have confirmed the existence of over 5,000 exoplanets orbiting other stars.
Black Hole Spaghettification. If you fell into a black hole, you would be stretched out like spaghetti.
ISS Speed. The International Space Station orbits Earth every 90 minutes at a speed of 17,500 mph.
Moon drifting away. The Moon is moving away from Earth at a rate of about 3.8 cm per year.
Saturn's Rings. Saturn's rings are made mostly of ice particles, some as small as dust, others as big as mountains.
Space Junk. There are over 128 million pieces of debris smaller than 1 cm orbiting Earth.
Uranus Tilt. Uranus spins on its side, likely due to a massive collision early in its history.
Temperature Extremes. The temperature in the void of space is about -270.45 degrees Celsius.
Pulsars. Pulsars are magnetized rotating neutron stars that emit beams of electromagnetic radiation.
Andromeda Collision. The Andromeda galaxy is on a collision course with the Milky Way, expected in 4.5 billion years.
Water in Space. Astronomers have found a massive water vapor cloud holding 140 trillion times the mass of water in Earth's oceans.
Cost of Spacesuit. A full NASA space suit costs approximately $12 million.
First Dog in Space. Laika was the first animal to orbit Earth, launched by the USSR in 1957.
Pluto's Heart. Pluto has a large heart-shaped glacier made of nitrogen ice.
Ganymede. Jupiter's moon Ganymede is the largest moon in the solar system, bigger than Mercury.
Solar Flares. A single solar flare can release the energy equivalent of millions of 100-megaton hydrogen bombs.
Theory of Relativity. Time passes slower the closer you are to a massive object, a phenomenon known as time dilation.
Kuiper Belt. A region beyond Neptune filled with icy bodies and dwarf planets.
Oort Cloud. A theoretical shell of icy objects that exist in the outermost reaches of the solar system.
Goldilocks Zone. The habitable zone around a star where conditions are just right for liquid water to exist.
Fermi Paradox. The contradiction between the lack of evidence for extraterrestrial civilizations and high estimates for their probability.
Cosmic Microwave Background. The afterglow radiation left over from the Big Bang.
Lagrange Points. Positions in space where the gravitational forces of two large bodies balance the centrifugal force felt by a smaller body.
Tidal Locking. The moon is tidally locked to Earth, meaning we always see the same face.
Variable Stars. Stars that change in brightness over time.
Supernova. The explosive death of a massive star.
Nebula. A giant cloud of dust and gas in space, often a nursery for new stars.
Quasars. Extremely luminous active galactic nuclei.
Event Horizon. The boundary around a black hole beyond which nothing can escape.
Wormholes. Theoretical passages through space-time that could create shortcuts for long journeys.
Space Elevator. A proposed type of planet-to-space transportation system.
Terraforming. The hypothetical process of deliberately modifying the atmosphere of a planet to make it habitable.
Search for Life. SETI is an organization dedicated to searching for extraterrestrial intelligence.
Multiverse. The theory that there are multiple universes existing parallel to our own.
Goat Discovery. Legend has it that Ethiopian shepherds first noticed the effects of coffee when their goats started dancing after eating coffee berries.
World's Second Commodity. Coffee is the second most traded commodity in the world, surpassed only by crude oil.
Espresso Meaning. Espresso comes from the Italian word meaning 'pressed out', referring to the way it is made.
Hawaii Coffee. Hawaii is the only state in the United States that grows coffee commercially.
Finland's Addiction. Finland consumes the most coffee in the world per capita.
Beethoven's Brew. Beethoven was obsessive about his coffee, using exactly 60 beans per cup.
Fruit, Not Bean. Coffee beans are actually the pits of a cherry-like fruit.
Decaf Process. Coffee is decaffeinated by steaming the unroasted beans or soaking them in a solvent.
Kopi Luwak. The most expensive coffee in the world comes from the dung of the Asian palm civet.
Banned in Mecca. Coffee was banned in Mecca in 1511 because it was believed to stimulate radical thinking.
Instant Coffee. George Washington invented instant coffee... not the president, but a Belgian man living in Guatemala.
Two Types. There are two main types of coffee: Arabica (mild, aromatic) and Robusta (bitter, high caffeine).
Americano Origin. American soldiers in WWII would dilute their espresso with water to mimic the coffee back home, creating the Americano.
Coffee Belt. All coffee in the world grows in the 'Bean Belt', between the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn.
Caffeine Half-Life. The half-life of caffeine is about 6 hours, meaning if you drink a cup at 4pm, half is still in your system at 10pm.
First Webcam. The first webcam was invented at Cambridge University to monitor a coffee pot.
Brazil's Dominance. Brazil produces about 40% of the world's coffee.
Boston Tea Party. After the Boston Tea Party, it became patriotic for Americans to drink coffee instead of tea.
Turkish Proverbs. A Turkish proverb describes coffee as 'Black as hell, strong as death, and sweet as love'.
Bach's Coffee Cantata. J.S. Bach wrote a comedic opera about a woman addicted to coffee.
Chlorogenic Acid. Coffee contains chlorogenic acid, which helps slow down the absorption of sugar.
Light vs Dark Roast. Light roast coffee actually has slightly more caffeine than dark roast.
Cappuccino Name. Named after the Capuchin friars because the color resembled their robes.
Fair Trade. Fair Trade coffee ensures farmers are paid a fair price and work in good conditions.
Cold Brew. Cold brew is made by steeping grounds in cold water for 12-24 hours, resulting in lower acidity.
Poison Warning. Voltaire supposedly drank 50 cups a day. When told it was a slow poison, he said 'I think it must be, for I have been drinking it for eighty-five years and am not dead yet'.
Grounds for Fuel. Scientists are developing ways to turn used coffee grounds into biodiesel.
Q Graders. Certified coffee tasters are called Q Graders, similar to sommeliers for wine.
Slurping. Professional coffee tasters slurp coffee to spray it across their entire palate.
Cascara. A tea made from the dried skins of the coffee fruit.
Irish Coffee. Invented to warm up frozen American passengers leaving from Foynes, Ireland.
Antioxidants. For many Americans, coffee is the number one source of antioxidants in their diet.
Espresso Caffeine. A single shot of espresso has less caffeine than a standard cup of drip coffee.
Blossom Time. A coffee tree takes 3 to 4 years to mature and produce its first crop.
Divorce Reason. In ancient Arab culture, a woman could legally divorce her husband if he didn't provide enough coffee.
Stock Market. The London Stock Exchange started in a coffee house.
Insurance. Lloyd's of London, the insurance market, also started in a coffee house.
Largest Cup. The largest cup of coffee ever made held over 6,000 gallons.
Mocha. Named after the port city of Mocha in Yemen.
Coffee Bans. Sweden banned coffee five times between 1756 and 1817.
Growing Conditions. Coffee needs rich soil, mild temperatures, frequent rain, and shaded sun.
Peaberry. A natural mutation where the coffee cherry contains only one bean instead of two, prized for flavor.
Flat White. A coffee drink consisting of espresso with microfoam, originating from Australia/New Zealand.
Macchiato. Means 'marked' or 'stained' - espresso marked with a dollop of foam.
Sustainable Farming. Shade-grown coffee preserves biodiversity and is better for the environment.
French Press. Actually patented by an Italian designer in 1929.
Ethiopian Ceremony. A traditional coffee ceremony in Ethiopia can take hours and involves roasting beans on the spot.
Green Coffee. Unroasted coffee beans are green and can be stored for long periods.
Robusta Resistance. Robusta plants are more resistant to disease and pests than Arabica.
Latte Art. The method of preparing milk foam to create patterns on the surface of espresso drinks.
